title: Mark Herrmann
text:
Mark Donald Herrmann (born January 8, 1959) is a former American college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for twelve seasons during the 1980s and 1990s. Herrmann played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for <a href="Purdue%20University">Purdue University</a>, and was recognized as an <a href="All-American">All-American</a>. He subsequently played professionally for four different NFL teams. After retiring as a player, he became the Associate Director of Educational Programs for the <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">NCAA</a>, and currently works as a broadcaster for local football after serving on the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> broadcast crew for nearly a decade.
Early years.
Herrmann was born in <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a> and raised in <a href="Carmel%2C%20Indiana">Carmel, Indiana</a>, where he played <a href="high%20school%20football">high school football</a> for <a href="Carmel%20High%20School%20%28Carmel%2C%20Indiana%29">Carmel High School</a>. He also played on Carmel's state championship <a href="basketball">basketball</a> team in 1977.
College career.
Herrmann attended <a href="Purdue%20University">Purdue University</a>, where he played for coach <a href="Jim%20Young%20%28American%20football%20coach%29">Jim Young</a>'s <a href="Purdue%20Boilermakers%20football">Purdue Boilermakers football</a> team from 1977 to 1980. Herrmann had an impressive college career; in 1980 he was recognized as a consensus first-team All-American, he was selected as the <a href="Big%20Ten%20Conference">Big Ten Conference</a>'s Most Valuable Player, and he finished fourth in voting for the <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a>. His 9,946 career passing yards set an NCAA record (which has since been broken). He is one of only three Purdue quarterbacks to start in three consecutive <a href="bowl%20game">bowl game</a>s (<a href="Drew%20Brees">Drew Brees</a> did the same, and <a href="Kyle%20Orton">Kyle Orton</a> started four straight). Herrmann won all three of his bowl games, and was selected Most Valuable Player in each of them: the 1978 <a href="Peach%20Bowl">Peach Bowl</a>, the 1979 <a href="Bluebonnet%20Bowl">Bluebonnet Bowl</a>, and the 1980 <a href="Liberty%20Bowl">Liberty Bowl</a>. He also holds the Liberty Bowl record for passing touchdowns.
He was elected to the <a href="College%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">College Football Hall of Fame</a> in May 2010.
Professional career.
Herrmann was drafted by the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a> in 1981, but did not play in his first year out of college. In 1982, he appeared in two games, but at the end of the season he was traded to the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a> as part of the deal that brought <a href="John%20Elway">John Elway</a> to Denver. In 1983–84 Herrmann saw limited action with the Colts, first at Baltimore and then at Indianapolis. In 1985, he was traded to the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a>, where he played for three seasons and performed well as the backup to <a href="Dan%20Fouts">Dan Fouts</a>. Herrmann then played for the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a> in 1988–89, and returned to the Colts for three seasons before retiring in 1992.
Herrmann appeared in just 40 games during his 11-year pro career, completing 334 passes in 561 attempts (59.5%) for a total of 4,015 yards. He threw 16 touchdown passes and was intercepted 36 times.
Personal life.
Herrmann lives in Indianapolis with his wife Susie. He has three children.
